articles.title: More than 100 moons were discovered in our own solar system in 2025
articles.summary: Astronomers discovered a new moon of Uranus and hundreds of moons around Saturn over the past year, and there may be many more yet to be found
articles.content:
Astronomers discovered a new moon of Uranus and hundreds of moons around Saturn over the past year, and there may be many more yet to be found

Uranus’s new moon, S/2025 U1, was spotted using the James Webb Space Telescope NASA/ESA/CSA/STScI/M. El Moutamid (SwRI)/M. Hedman (University of Idaho)

This year, astronomers discovered more than 100 previously unknown moons in our own solar system. There may be many more yet to be discovered, and cataloguing them could help us better understand how planets form.

In March, Edward Ashton at Academia Sinica in Taiwan and his colleagues discovered 128 moons around Saturn, bringing the planet’s total to 274. The team gathered hours’ worth of images from the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope in Hawaii and stacked them on top of each other to spot objects that are otherwise too dim to see.

Ashton’s team now has the right to name the new moons, although Saturn’s moons are so numerous that many are no longer given informal names.

In August, a small and dim new moon was found in orbit around Uranus, bringing the planet’s total to 29. Maryame El Moutamid at Southwest Research Institute in Colorado and her colleagues made the discovery using 10 long-exposure infrared images taken by NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope.

The team remains tight-lipped on potential names for the moon, so it still has the provisional name S/2025 U1. In time, it will probably be named along the same lines as 27 of Uranus’s moons, which take a character’s name from one of Shakespeare’s plays. This convention dates back to the discovery of the planet’s first two moons, Titania and Oberon, in 1787.

Nigel Mason at the University of Kent, UK, says there are likely to be many more moons to be discovered in our solar system, particularly around Neptune and Uranus, although the largest ones have probably already been mapped.

“Everybody always likes to find new moons and everybody always likes to think about what they’re going to call them,” he says. “It’s an exciting moment. It’s a bit of a legacy.”

The more we catalogue and measure our local moons, the more we can find out about how they are created and use that information to update our models of planet formation, says Mason.

“Why are there so many? What is it that triggered [planets] to make 40, 50, 60 of such varying shapes and sizes? That’s why they’re exciting,” he says. “It’s not just stamp collecting. It really is ‘wow’. Really surprisingly, the whole planet-formation process is not as well as understood as we think.”
articles.reasoning: The discovery of over 100 new moons in our solar system using advanced telescopes represents a significant scientific breakthrough that enhances our understanding of planetary formation. The impact is broad, inspiring curiosity and expanding human knowledge about our cosmic neighborhood.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers discover over 100 new moons in our solar system in 2025
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2025, astronomers used powerful telescopes to explore planets in our solar system, searching for moons that orbit them. Moons are smaller objects that circle planets, and finding new ones helps scientists learn more about how planets and their systems form.

**What happened** – Over the past year, astronomers found more than 100 new moons. In March, a team led by Edward Ashton in Taiwan discovered 128 new moons around Saturn, increasing its total moons to 274. They used images from the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope by stacking many pictures to see dim objects. Later, in August, Maryame El Moutamid and her team found a small new moon orbiting Uranus using the James Webb Space Telescope. This moon is called S/2025 U1 for now and is Uranus’s 29th moon.

**Impact** – These discoveries show that there are many more moons than previously known, especially around giant planets like Saturn and Uranus. Finding so many moons helps scientists understand why some planets have dozens of moons with different shapes and sizes. This knowledge challenges and improves current ideas about how planets and their moons form and evolve.

**What’s next step** – Scientists expect to find more moons, particularly around planets like Neptune and Uranus. The new moons will be studied in detail, and eventually, they will be named—often following traditions like naming Uranus’s moons after Shakespearean characters. Continued discoveries will help update scientific models of the solar system.

**One-sentence takeaway** – In 2025, astronomers found over 100 new moons around planets like Saturn and Uranus, deepening our understanding of how moons and planets form.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes découvrent plus de 100 nouvelles lunes dans notre système solaire en 2025
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2025, des astronomes ont utilisé des télescopes puissants pour explorer les planètes de notre système solaire à la recherche de nouvelles lunes. Les lunes sont des objets plus petits qui tournent autour des planètes, et en découvrir aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre la formation des planètes et de leurs systèmes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Au cours de l’année, les astronomes ont découvert plus de 100 nouvelles lunes. En mars, une équipe dirigée par Edward Ashton à Taïwan a trouvé 128 nouvelles lunes autour de Saturne, portant son total à 274. Ils ont utilisé des images du télescope Canada-France-Hawaï en combinant plusieurs photos pour voir des objets faibles. En août, Maryame El Moutamid et son équipe ont découvert une petite nouvelle lune autour d’Uranus grâce au télescope spatial James Webb. Cette lune, nommée provisoirement S/2025 U1, est la 29e lune d’Uranus.

**Impact** – Ces découvertes montrent qu’il y a beaucoup plus de lunes que ce que l’on pensait, surtout autour des grandes planètes comme Saturne et Uranus. Trouver autant de lunes aide les scientifiques à comprendre pourquoi certaines planètes ont des dizaines de lunes de formes et tailles différentes. Ces informations améliorent les idées sur la façon dont les planètes et leurs lunes se forment et évoluent.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques s’attendent à découvrir encore plus de lunes, notamment autour de Neptune et Uranus. Les nouvelles lunes seront étudiées en détail et recevront bientôt un nom, souvent selon la tradition de nommer les lunes d’Uranus d’après des personnages de Shakespeare. Ces découvertes continueront à enrichir les modèles scientifiques du système solaire.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En 2025, les astronomes ont découvert plus de 100 nouvelles lunes autour de planètes comme Saturne et Uranus, approfondissant notre compréhension de la formation des lunes et des planètes.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos descubren más de 100 lunas nuevas en nuestro sistema solar en 2025
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2025, los astrónomos usaron telescopios potentes para explorar los planetas de nuestro sistema solar en busca de lunas que los orbitan. Las lunas son objetos más pequeños que giran alrededor de los planetas, y encontrarlas ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor cómo se forman los planetas y sus sistemas.

**Qué pasó** – Durante el último año, los astrónomos descubrieron más de 100 lunas nuevas. En marzo, un equipo liderado por Edward Ashton en Taiwán encontró 128 nuevas lunas alrededor de Saturno, aumentando el total a 274. Usaron imágenes del telescopio Canada-France-Hawaii apilando muchas fotos para ver objetos muy tenues. Luego, en agosto, Maryame El Moutamid y su equipo descubrieron una luna pequeña alrededor de Urano con el telescopio espacial James Webb. Esta luna se llama provisionalmente S/2025 U1 y es la luna número 29 de Urano.

**Impacto** – Estos descubrimientos muestran que hay muchas más lunas de lo que se creía, especialmente alrededor de planetas grandes como Saturno y Urano. Encontrar tantas lunas ayuda a los científicos a entender por qué algunos planetas tienen docenas de lunas con diferentes formas y tamaños. Esta información mejora las ideas sobre cómo se forman y evolucionan los planetas y sus lunas.

**Próximo paso** – Se espera que los científicos encuentren más lunas, especialmente alrededor de Neptuno y Urano. Las nuevas lunas serán estudiadas con detalle y eventualmente recibirán nombres, siguiendo tradiciones como nombrar las lunas de Urano con personajes de Shakespeare. Estos hallazgos seguirán ayudando a actualizar los modelos científicos del sistema solar.

**Resumen en una frase** – En 2025, los astrónomos descubrieron más de 100 lunas nuevas alrededor de planetas como Saturno y Urano, ampliando nuestro conocimiento sobre la formación de lunas y planetas.
